message.content: {"steps":[{"output":"\\lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n \\sqrt{\\frac{3n}{3n+k}}","explanation":"We need to evaluate the limit of the sequence as \\( n \\to \\infty \\)."},{"output":"\\sqrt{\\frac{3n}{3n+k}} = \\sqrt{\\frac{3n}{3n(1 + \\frac{k}{3n})}} = \\sqrt{\\frac{1}{1 + \\frac{k}{3n}}}","explanation":"Simplify the expression inside the square root."},{"output":"\\sqrt{\\frac{1}{1 + \\frac{k}{3n}}} \\approx 1 - \\frac{1}{2} \\cdot \\frac{k}{3n} = 1 - \\frac{k}{6n}","explanation":"Use the first-order Taylor expansion for \\( \\sqrt{1+x} \\approx 1 + \\frac{x}{2} \\) when \\( x \\) is small."},{"output":"\\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n \\left(1 - \\frac{k}{6n}\\right) = \\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n 1 - \\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n \\frac{k}{6n}","explanation":"Separate the sum into two parts."},{"output":"\\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n 1 = 1","explanation":"The first sum is simply \\( n \\) times 1, divided by \\( n \\)."},{"output":"\\frac{1}{n} \\sum_{k=1}^n \\frac{k}{6n} = \\frac{1}{6n^2} \\sum_{k=1}^n k = \\frac{1}{6n^2} \\cdot \\frac{n(n+1)}{2} = \\frac{n+1}{12n}","explanation":"Use the formula for the sum of the first \\( n \\) natural numbers: \\( \\sum_{k=1}^n k = \\frac{n(n+1)}{2} \\)."},{"output":"\\lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\left(1 - \\frac{n+1}{12n}\\right) = \\lim_{n \\to \\infty} \\left(1 - \\frac{1}{12} - \\frac{1}{12n}\\right) = 1 - \\frac{1}{12} = \\frac{11}{12}","explanation":"Evaluate the limit as \\( n \\to \\infty \\). The term \\( \\frac{1}{12n} \\to 0 \\)."}],"final_answer":"\\MC: boxed{2}"}
